docs.snippet: FORTRESS MONROE, Thursday, Dec. 19, Via BALTIMORE, Friday, Dec. 20.  The steamer Illinois left for New-York early this morning.

headline.main: NEWS FROM FORTRESS MONROE.; Exchange of Prisoners--News from the Rebel States--Reports of Operations at Port Royal--Rebel Accounts of Affairs in the West, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Thursday, Dec. 19, Via BALTIMORE, Friday, Dec. 20. The steamer Illinois left for New-York early this morning.

docs.snippet: CAIRO, Friday, Dec. 13, 1861. We begin to have stirring times among both  land and naval forces, which indicate that something will shortly transpire which will strike terror to the rebels below here.

headline.main: THE WAR IN THE WEST.; The Preparations for the Expedition Into the Heart of Rebeldom. Marshaling the Gunboats and the Mortar Floats. HOW COLUMBUS IS TO BE REDUCED. Rebel Fortifications on the Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers. View of the Great Strategic Movements in Kentucky. The Advance of Gen. Buell Across Green River. BUCKNER TO BE OVERWHELMED. Interesting Intelligence from Missouri and Kansas. IMPORTANT FROM CAIRO. Stirring Preparations for an Advance--Probable Demonstration Against Columbus--The Mortar Boats--Skirmishes--Movements of the Rebels, &c. Preparations for Taking Columbus--Skirmishing at Bird's Point--Withdrawal ofTroops from the Charleston Road--Immense Congregation of Rebel Troops onthe Mississippi--The Success of the UnionGunboats--Flags of Truce--CommodoreHollins and His Battering-ram, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: CAIRO, Friday, Dec. 13, 1861. We begin to have stirring times among both land and naval forces, which indicate that something will shortly transpire which will strike terror to the rebels below here.

headline.main: LETTER FROM COL. COCORAN.; HOW THE NATIONAL PRISONERS ARE TREATED BY THE REBELS.

docs.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON JAIL, S.C., Tuesday, Nov. 19, 1861. MY EVER DEAR FRIEND: After all the privation and insults to which we have been subjected since prisoners of war, and when the worst passions ought to be satisfied, we find that we have yet another and the worst ordeal to pass through.

docs.snippet: At a complimentary dinner given to Mr. BRIGHT, M.P., at Rochdale, Dec. 4, that distinguished gentleman made a very long and eloquent speech, devoted exclusively to the American question. In alluding to the Mason and Slidell affair, he said:

headline.main: MR. BRIGHT ON THE TRENT AFFAIR.

docs.lead_paragraph: At a complimentary dinner given to Mr. BRIGHT, M.P., at Rochdale, Dec. 4, that distinguished gentleman made a very long and eloquent speech, devoted exclusively to the American question. In alluding to the Mason and Slidell affair, he said:

docs.snippet: The steamer S.R. Paulding has arrived from Port Royal, bringing news of the safe and successful occupation of Beaufort by our troops. The health of the men was good, and the weather fine.

headline.main: OUR FORTRESS MONROE CORRESPONDENCE.; AFFAIRS AT HATTERAS INLET SICKNESS THERE THE PROVISIONS FOR THE SUFFERING NATIVES, ETC.

docs.lead_paragraph: The steamer S.R. Paulding has arrived from Port Royal, bringing news of the safe and successful occupation of Beaufort by our troops. The health of the men was good, and the weather fine.

docs.snippet: HEALTH OF THE MAYOR. There was another unfavorable turn yesterday in the disease by which Mayor KALBRLEISCH is prostrated upon a bed of sickness, and it is feared that he will not recover.

headline.main: BROOKLYN NEWS.; MURDER WILL OUT. DAVID SMITH (colored)

docs.lead_paragraph: HEALTH OF THE MAYOR. There was another unfavorable turn yesterday in the disease by which Mayor KALBRLEISCH is prostrated upon a bed of sickness, and it is feared that he will not recover.

headline.main: THE RUMORED INSANITY OF GEN. SHERMAN.

docs.snippet: The excitement could hardly have been greater at New-York, when the news of the capture of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON arrived there, than it was at Paris, yesterday, when the same news arrived here. The Unionists shouted with joy at the bold stroke,...

headline.main: FROM PARIS.; How the Trent Affair is Received in France Opinions of the French Press Gen. Scott, etc.

docs.lead_paragraph: The excitement could hardly have been greater at New-York, when the news of the capture of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON arrived there, than it was at Paris, yesterday, when the same news arrived here. The Unionists shouted with joy at the bold stroke, while the Secessionists swore loud and long, and predicted an immediate war with England.
